709788f-b.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - 41st Street (West)
709788f-b.text:
Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street, towards Times
Scquare. North of 42nd Street this thoroughfare loses it's
identity, becomming a portion of Times 3Quare: the buildings on
all sides bearing Broadway addresses. The Paramount Building
which is prominently shown is an outstanding example of that
practice. Note the Hotel Hermitage at the left margin. This
atructure adjoins the low building at the S.W. corner of 42nd
Street. On the opposite corner (N.W.) is the Rialto Theatre.
This is s oon to be renovated and will present a different ex-
ternal app6arance..
May 27, 1935
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr
NO RGPRODUCTIONS

709789f-a.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - 41st Street (West)
709789f-a.text:
Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street and viewing
towards Times Square, a district that absorbs this thorough-
fare, from 42nd to 47th Streets. Prominently shown is the
dominant Paramount Building occupying the 45rd to 44th Street
frontage. Above same is the Hotel Astor. The old Rialto
Theatre is being demolished in View 1. A two story taxpayer,
containing stores and a restaurant was erected here. View 2
is taken during the track removal project conducted by the
W. P. A. Note the bus that has replaced the street cars.
July 6, 1935
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
June 4, 1937
W. P. A. photo
Five Boroughs Project
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

709790f-b.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - 41st Street (West)
709790f-b.text:
Seventh Avenue, north from W. 4lst Street, towards Times
Square. North of 42nd Street this thoroughfare loses its
identity, becoming a portion of Times Sduare: the buildings on
all sides bearing Broadway addresses. The Paramount Building
which is prominently shown is an outstanding example of that
practice. The toer-like structure outlined by the latter, is
at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, and is a portion of the
improverwnts made to the building housing the Rialto Theatre.
Opposite same, and partially seen on the right, is the westerly
side of the Times Building. At the left, between 41st and 42nd
Streets are, the Stanley Theatre (motion picture) and the Hotel
Rerritage.
These photostats (negative and positive) are reproductions
of original photographs that were discoloring in the files.
November 9, 1936
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr
NO RDPRODUCTIONS
